repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
This commit changes `languagetree.lua` so that it creates a scratch buffer under the hood when dealing with string parsers. This will make it much easier to just use extmarks whenever we need to track injection trees in `languagetree.lua`. This also allows us to remove the `treesitter.c` code for parsing a string directly.

Note that the string parser's scratch buffer has `set noeol nofixeol` so that the parsed source exactly matches the passed-in string.

<!--
  Thank you for contributing to Neovim!
  If this is your first time, check out https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#pull-requests-prs
  for our PR guidelines.
-->

comment_regular_data.body:
Hi,

Is string parser used internally in Neovim anywhere?

~This change drastically impacts performance for plugins that rely on tree-sitter string parsing. We are using it in https://github.com/nvim-orgmode/orgmode to parse the files to build up an agenda, without the need to open up each of the files as a buffer. For me, it increased from less than 0.5 sec, to 4+ seconds, with just around 20 files. There are users that have hundreds of them.~

~Is there a chance to have this working as before, but behind some configuration option, or option provided to the language tree? We don't really need any injections parsing, just parsing the top level tree.~

I refactored a bit and performance is back to normal. The only downside is that now we get a bunch of unlisted buffers opened.

> ow we get a bunch of unlisted buffers opened.

Oh we should fix that, but I thought this PR re-used one scratch buffer?

> Oh we should fix that, but I thought this PR re-used one scratch buffer?

It does, sorry for not being more specific. I'm just saying generally. Previously, when using string parser, there was no need to create an unlisted buffer to be able to parse the file.

Buffers are data structures, no one should care when scratch buffers are created. We need to find a way for people to care less about them, maybe by using very big numbers for unlisted scratch buffers.

Or imaginary numbers ðŸ˜¬ 

`nvim_list_bufs2()` -- or a new Lua API if we don't want to waste the Nvim API space on it -- should just take a flag to allow filtering unlisted (or possibly other kinds of) buffers.

> I refactored a bit and performance is back to normal. The only downside is that now we get a bunch of unlisted buffers opened.

Out of interest what did you do to get performance back?

> Out of interest what did you do to get performance back?

Previously, if there was no buffer for a filename, I always used the string parser, which basically created the scratch buffers all the time because they are unnamed. Now, I create an unlisted buffer manually with the correct name, and always use that as a source for tree-sitter. Basically stopped using string parser.
Hmm I would say that is more of a workaround than a real solution. Maybe we should revert this? It didn't really save that much code.

I left a comment on https://github.com/nvim-orgmode/orgmode/pull/1041, but I think the main issue here is that downstream users relying on `type(parser:source()) ~= 'number'` as an equivalent to `parser:is_string_parser()` have lost that functionality, which i should've marked as a breaking change... i have to go to work but some initial thoughts (I have not tested this):

See https://github.com/nvim-orgmode/orgmode/pull/1041/files#diff-88a3681fabfeb9cbe5d58ab2f1297200010cee4832c08ca95bce382ea41e07ddL926: before this PR, `type(self.parser:source()) == 'number'` would've been a no-op, because in that block we are already guaranteed to be using a string parser. This was inconsequential before, but now this condition always returns `true` which needlessly recreates the string parser every time. let me know if i'm wrong @kristijanhusak

> `nvim_list_bufs2()` -- or a new Lua API if we don't want to waste the Nvim API space on it

Reminder that current API functions will be extensible after https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/31903 is resolved, which we have a [clear path](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/33392) to achieving.

I solved my use case, but want to give a heads-up that this is affecting some of the different usages, for example: https://github.com/Saghen/blink.cmp/issues/2205

I'm not sure how much complexity we are removing with this, but I somewhat agree with https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/35988#issuecomment-3366065984

> I'm not sure how much complexity we are removing with this

The main point of this PR is not the savings here but that it opens the door for #36030 (which is a significant improvement).

The alternative would be to decouple string parsers completely from buffer parsers (potentially at the cost of reduced functionality or performance).

E.g., would a simplified string parser that doesn't use buffers at the cost of not supporting injections work for your use case?

> E.g., would a simplified string parser that doesn't use buffers at the cost of not supporting injections work for your use case?

We could improve this a bit. We could support string parsers with injections but they must use buffers internally, and string parsers without injections can avoid using buffers. 

From what I know, that would solve most usecases. If you want injections then you need to pay for them.

> E.g., would a simplified string parser that doesn't use buffers at the cost of not supporting injections work for your use case?

Just to clarify, by "not supporting injections" you mean accessing the tree of the injected language?
If that's the case, then yes, that would work for me, and also for the blink.cmp issue I linked.

> We could support string parsers with injections but they must use buffers internally, and string parsers without injections can avoid using buffers.

This sounds like a good middle ground. How would we determine if injection parsing is needed, via options?

> Just to clarify, by "not supporting injections" you mean accessing the tree of the injected language?

No, I mean "no injections, period" -- you get the specified root language and that's it.

labels.description: changes that are not features or bugfixes
labels.name: refactor

title: refactor(treesitter): use scratch buffer for string parser
